intro: Allium pseudoampeloprasum, commonly known as the Armenian leek, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus and Central Asia. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its long, slender, hollow leaves and bulbous underground stems. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces clusters of small, white or pale purple flowers in the summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it suitable for rock gardens and alpine settings. Due to its ornamental value and culinary uses, it is occasionally cultivated by gardeners and herbalists.
